comments.text:
+Dimitriye Danilović
I haven't heard of proper studies of people's color perceptions comparing 
let's say Full HD vs. 4K displays, both same technology and both color 
calibrated evenly, both at the same and far enough distance, both 
displaying the same content that was natively in 4K (so that there is 
*downscaling* for that content to be shown on the full HD panel) and blind 
results of the study favoring color perception on the higher resolutions at 
such distances where you don't even see the pixels of the lower resolution 
panel. Is there is any link you can provide that backs up what you say, 
please share.

On the other hand, one (bad) thing about higher resolution is the fact that 
you have to in fact *upscale* any content that is natively in lower 
resolutions (like 1920x1080 seen on 4K panels), and upscaling is very hard 
to do well (in fact much harder than downscaling); upscaling can introduce 
artifacts that would be easily visible at the proper viewing distances on 
the higher resolution panels, but that simply wouldn't exist watching that 
content on its own native resolution at its own proper viewing distances.
comments.author: Raul Saavedra

comments.text:
+Crisp Hotdog Forgot to mention, also, higher resolution screens also pay 
off in another way. While your eyes can't make out the difference in 
individual pixels, they can make out a difference in the way the colors 
blend together. Anti-aliasing technology still can't match up with an 
actual higher resolution.
comments.author: Dimitriye Danilović

comments.text:
How you should do it:
1. Close 1 eye.
2. Fixate what you think is the center of your view on a fixated point, 
like for example the exit button of your browser.
3. Stretch your arm and hold the thumb up (from the hand on the same side 
as your open eye).
4. move your hand so your thumbnail is over the fixated point.
5. While keeping the point in the background fixated really slowly move 
your thumb away horizontally in the direction of your open eye (when using 
left eye left, right eye right). Keep the point fixated but focus on your 
thumb.
7.At a special point (approx. 4-5 inches away from the fix point) you 
should not be able to see your thumb anymore if you did everything correct.

comments.author: Ken Bailey

comments.text:
+Ken Bailey Can't you see that something's wrong?

If a game runs at its full potential in 1080p and 60 fps, it is *because* 
it runs in 1080p and 60 fps. I would not be able to run at the same 
resolution and frame rate, had it had to display a more demanding game like 
most of the AAA titles that the PS4 and Xbone has to. It would then run *even 
worse* than PS4 and Xbone, given that it has worse hardware. On the other 
hand, had the Nintendo games been released for PS4 and Xbone, they would've 
been able to run them at 1080p in 60fps just fine.

How demanding a game is, dictates at which resolution and frame rate said 
game can run at. Running at a higher frame rate and/or resolution results 
in a more demanding task for the console. In this case, said game would 
have to be less demanding by turning down the details in the games, if you 
want to run it at 1080p 60fps.
comments.author: Dirty Poul

comments.text:
Did I ever say they had to? I'm just using simple logic.  If a game uses 
the FULL POTENTIAL of the system (no matter WHAT game and how much detailed 
it is) and STILL runs at 1080/60, then there's no excuse for other systems 
that are similarly built.

Instead of insulting your lack of intelligence *whoops, I just did...*
AHEM...
Anyways, Instead of doing that, I'll explain what a blind spot is, and why 
every living creature on this planet has one. (Yes, even you).
A blind spot is an area outside your range of vision.
For instance. If you are looking forward, and cannot see directly behind 
you, that would be a blind spot.
Looking to your right, You can't look to your left at the same time, and 
vice versa. Looking up? You can't see below you, etc. etc. .

top_comment.text:
How many images can an average computer monitor display? Clearly there are 
only a finite number of pixels, and a finite number of states they could be 
in, so there should be a (very large) finite number of images. But, the 
cool part is that this would include not only every picture ever taken or 
document typed, but every one not taken or typed, or cooler, not yet taken 
or typed. Could a program be written for this? While there would obviously 
be a greater number of false or abstract pictures, there is a practical 
application. If we restrict the program to every possible text document, or 
blueprint, we would get instructions for every invention ever to exist and 
an explanation of their operating principles, every mathematical proof 
possible, and every building that could be built. Again, we would also have 
a (nearly) infinite number of incorrect proofs and unstable buildings and 
broken inventions, but programs exist today that can filter those out. I 
thought that might be cool.﻿

comments.text:
Let's do the math. Imagine the monitor only had 2x2 pixels. Each pixel can 
show one of 256x256x256=16,77 million possible colors (common "true color" 
or 24-bit depth color spec). Now you chose one of those colors for one 
pixel, and you have to go through all other possible combinations of colors 
for the rest of the pixels. So in a simple 2x2 monitor, you already have 
(2^24)x(2^24)x(2^24)x(2^24), or 2^(24x4) = 2^96 possible images or 
combinations.

If you have Full HD or 1920x1080 pixels, that's more than 2 million pixels, 
or exactly 2073600 pixels. The number of possible images on such a monitor 
is 2^(24x2073600). That's the number two raised to a power of almost 50 
million, or *10 raised to the power of almost 15 million*. That means, *a 
one followed by 15 million zeros*.

It's pretty hard to understand what a seriously large number that is.

Take into account there are only 3.15x10^7 seconds in a full year. In fact, 
the universe itself has just about 14 billion years of age, or 14x10^9 
years. That totals just 4.35x10^26 nanoseconds, so less than a one followed 
by 27 zeros. But the number of images we are considering here is, again, a 
one followed by 15 million zeros! So after the entire age of the universe 
looking at different images on this monitor one every nanosecond, and 
without repetitions, we still would have covered just 4.35 E 26 images. How 
many other different ones to go? Well, pretty much we ain't seen nothing 
yet.

Take into account that 10^15000000 (let's call it P as in my blog post) is 
actually 10 times Q=10^14999999, another very large number, just one order 
of magnitude smaller than P. So P = 10xQ. Let's call R the age of the 
universe in nanoseconds, so R=4.35x10^26. So using these letters, we just 
want to compute P - R, or in other words, 10^15000000 - 4.3510^26. How much 
is that?

P being 10Q, P - R is the same as 10Q - R, which is the same as 9Q + (Q - 
R). So after removing the apparent large number of images we've already 
seen (less than 10^27), we still have 9 times 10^14999999 images to go, 
plus another factor which is also almost as large as that Q: Q - R. But 
notice that such number Q - R is almost equal to Q, in fact, it is equal to 
9x10^14999998 + [10^14999998 - R]. And so and so on.

Basically, for all practical purposes, P - R is just the same P. I went 
through the above paragraph just for illustration of how insignificant is R 
(total number of nanoseconds in the entire age of the universe) compared to 
10^15000000. When adding or substracting numbers of such massively 
different orders of magnitude, you just keep the larger number untouched. 
It changes so insignificantly that for all practical purposes, the result 
is just as large.

So after the entire age of the universe watching different images without 
repetition, one every nanosecond, we literally ain't seen nothing yet 
compared to the total number of different images displayable by that 
monitor. A number amazingly large, even though we can represent it and name 
it rather briefly: *10^15000000*.
comments.author: Raul Saavedra

Formulae: Width × Height = All pixels on screen ÷ Mega Constant(10^6) = 
Megapixels

HD - 1920 × 1080 = 2073600 pixels ÷ 10^6 = ~2.0 Megapixels
4K -  4096 × 2160 = 8847360 pixels ÷ 10^6 = ~8.8 Megapixels
8K - 8192 × 4320 = 35389440 pixels ÷ 10^6 = ~35.3 Megapixels

So if we were to calculate 571 Mega pixels...

571 Megapixels × 10^6 = ~571000000 pixels = ~32768 × ~17426 = 32K+! (They 
might call it something else by then)

comments.text:
+Strazdas No.
I'm specificly talking about LEDs, in that specific test.

*Small rundown:*
- Get 2 power supplies that can give a 1.5V AC 50Hz output, where you can 
adjust the delay of frequency output (or do it yourself with an electronic 
contraption).
- Optional: flatten the voltage output with a diode if you're afraid of 
damaging the LEDs.
- Hook a red LED on one of the 2.
- Hook a blue LED on the other, with a delay of 0.5Hz.
- Aim both leds on a specific point on an object.
- You'll have 100 flashes per second, you'll see a yellow color.
- Slow down the frequency (lowering it) and keep the difference at 0.5Hz of 
what it's set at at the moment.
- You'll notice, that pretty close to 30Hz power supply output, which is 
close to 60 flashes per second, you will still see the yellow color.
- Once you start hitting under the 60 flashes per second, that the yellow 
stops being yellow, but is seperating into red and blue.

And on another thing, decent halogen lamps don't flicker at all.
With a decent DC electronic transformer build in, the light output will be 
constant.
So either you've seen cheap shitty halogen lamps, or you're making 
assumptions here that make no sense in basic electronics.

comments.text:
+Tikay Actually you're kind of both right, the reason you can't see flicker 
(each individual frame) is most likely because you own an LED/LCD or Plasma 
TV. LED and LCD's have pixel persistence which make seeing flicker (low 
framerate) hard as each pixel refresh is blurred into one another, Plasma 
TV's (modern ones) also use techniques such as PWM to eliminate flicker so 
it will not be visible because of this. OLD CRT TV's (even progressive) did 
not have blur problems and did not have any sub-field refresh abilities, 
they needed around 75/90FPS+ pumped into them to eliminate flicker 
depending on who you ask (everybody has different eye, some may only need 
around 80FPS whereas some may need as high as 110FPS etc).

enough for our eyes start to *comprehend*/see it as a continuous rate of

believed to receive higher quality than before, same as food).

100fps, wouldn't be able to watch youtube, as that's 30fps, and would cause

comments.text:
+LastTimeLord12 No, but you *can* test at which frame rate the eye stops 
taking all the information. At some point it stops being able to 
differentiate one from the other anymore.

Goes for coloring, old televisions (where the screen refreshed from top to 
bottom, or top->mid + mid->bottom), light effects, etc.

Frames per second tests were done to the human eye to see how low is 
enough. The lesser the frames needed in movies, whether it's dvd or 
television, the easier it is to handle.

So yes, the eye doesn't take pictures physically, but that doesn't mean we 
can see or differentiate frame to frame at high fps rates.

comments.text:
+CognizantxNight
DPI and PPI are different things.

It's a popular misconception that they're one and the same, but they're 
really not.
PPI is the real measure of resolution and it's perceivable quality to the 
viewer when we're measuring any perceivable resolution of anything ever 
that you're experiencing viewing objects on a computer display or other 
type of a panel or a device, really. The easily explainable formula for PPI 
is this: the more the resolution in relation to viewable panel's size is, 
the more PPI is. The more the viewable panel's size is, and the lesser it's 
resolution in relation to the said panel's size is, the lesser the PPI is.
Basically, you'll have a bigger PPI on a panel that would have smaller 
size, but greater resolution, and vice versa. No panel out there so far is 
able to get even remotely close to the real human's eye sheer PPI-wise, 
this is the main reason while we still don't have computers build in right 
into contact lenses or, hell, even eye implants which they usually show us 
in Cyber Punk Sci-Fi. That is because, actually, human's eye stops 
distinction of individual perceivable pixels at a point of 448 PPI exactly, 
but there is a quirk for this - it only does so at a viewing distance of 
roughly 10cm away from the viewable panel. This is roughly the distance 
from which you're looking at a smartphone while holding it in your right 
hand on a  moderately stretched out hand. The problem with this is that 
when you're bringing anything closer to your eye, even if it has much 
greater PPI than that of the aforementioned 448 mark, your brain begins 
literally protesting and your eyes demand much higher PPI than it asked for 
at the 10cm mark or further away. At a 5cm distance your eyes would demand 
for a PPI of at least 2000 points, before it starts protesting again, and 
no monitor/panel so far is able to provide that.
And to have a completely comfortable experience with something like lenses 
or eye implants, you'll actually need exactly that same PPI which your eye 
operates at in the real life, and since it's more than 4700 points, we 
really won't see this happening anytime soon, not even in the quite 
perceivable future.

That's for PPI.


Now DPI...
DPI is basically nothing more than just a measuring method for printing. 
You see, the thing is...printers don't print exact pixels. Printers operate 
by utilizing thousands of super-small needles that basically spill the ink 
out of their syringe-like noses and spread it across the area they could 
touch. DPI is literally that - Dots Per Inch. It literally describes that 
this measure counts how small the printer's ink needles are, how many of 
them are there, and thus which amount of dots they're able to cover with 
ink in relation to one inch of space of the provided paper/material. This 
isn't like PPI, because PPI is an outsider measure which only counts 
perceivable viewing resolution, PPI directly affects viewing quality. DPI 
is not. DPI is actually a parameter that affects a printer on a physical 
basis, it directly affects hardware inside the thing, not just on a 
perceivable quality scale like PPI. Sure, higher DPI does mean that you'll 
get higher quality/better detalization of the printed image/thing (this is 
especially true for the 3D printing, though there are some special quirks 
to that particular segment too), but it's mainly used only to describe 
number of ink needles and their size inside the printing heads of any 
printer, really. The more there is and the smaller they are (it's something 
like a tech-process for modern CPUs/GPUs: the smaller the manufacturing 
process is - the more stuff you can cram onto the same area), technically 
the better the result is, though this is not ALWAYS the case, since there 
are many more factors coming into play.


All in all, to sum it all up:
DPI and PPI are different things.
When you want to describe an overall perceivable resolution, please refer 
to PPI.

When you're talking about printing something, refer to DPI.

P.S. Such thing as a "DPI" and a "Polling Rate" of a computer mouse is 
actually a thing different than that of printer's DPI, so there are nuances 
too.

With your wording, I must remind that the TV is not the cause of your 
deteriorating vision. That is a myth from a very very old and short-lived 
type of TV, just one of those myths that stuck around for no rational 
reason. Naturally, a person with deteriorating vision will get closer to a 
TV, some people get the cause-and-effect relationship backward.

as often as needed. Although the trending unconfirmed myth these days is 
that such items help worsen vision in the long run, since muscles in the 
eye get to relax instead of working hard to focus vision. But being able to 
see well is more important, glasses are great.

plastic, glass, and wood along with other smooth non magnetic materials 
stick to them.  It is a trick that takes advantage of friction by leaning 
back slightly, having slightly more elastic skin that will conform to 
objects easier, and having slightly stickier bodily secretions.  Popping 
eye balls out of their sockets is done by tensing all the muscles around 
the eye to squeeze it out and then stopping to let it be pulled back in. 
 As for synesthesia, it is caused by brain signals being sent to areas of 
the brain that, according to normal human genetic coding, would not receive 
them, and was classified as faulty wiring.  Water allergies are the body 
overreacting to water on the skin and thinking it is more dangerous than it 
actually is, then trying to alert the human with pain; this was classified 
as faulty wiring for that reason.  Potters syndrome is a faulty build and 
can include missing body parts with a scientific explanation, so was both 
categories.  Hearing ones own eyeballs is caused by a hole in one of the 
bones in your ear so can be considered a missing body part.  I stand by

top_comment.text:
What does the world look like as it is? What if we saw everything as it 
happened, for instance, we would see a black hole 4 light years away right 
now, and the sun's 8 1/2 minute time wait to actually see the light coming 
from the sun, just disappeared? *I don't know if this makes sense*, but if 
we could see everything, even past the observable universe because light 
wouldn't have to travel to the Earth for us to see it, what would it look 
like?﻿
top_comment.author: BigRedProductions11

comments.text:
This question can go deeper than you might think. Physics relies on the use 
of constants; weight, time, speed of light. In reality, these aren't really 
constant unless looked at from a single point in space. Weight changes with 
elevation, as does time. Questions have been raised about the speed of 
light actually being constant. It's now known that gravity travels at the 
speed of light. So if the sun went away, not only would you not know it 
from looking at it during that 8 1/2 minutes, you wouldn't feel it either. 
Light and gravity also follow the inverse square law; as they travel, their 
intensity doesn't decrease in a linear fashion. Both the velocity factor 
and the inverse square act as a sort of shock absorber for the universe. 
When a planet moves in some far off galaxy, or the wind blows across a 
wheat field here on this planet - it affects every other thing - the shock 
absorber may dull the perception, but the action is still there, factoring 
in time.

The question you're asking is, what if we take away the shock absorber? 
Well, if you drive a car over a crack in the sidewalk, you don't feel it 
even though it happened. But, if you push a shopping cart over that same 
crack, the whole cart jumps in your hands instantly. Take away the shock 
absorber for the universe? Would you be in for a bumpy ride? You probably 
wouldn't know, beginning=end.

Instead of looking at the universe, realize you are part of it. Your mass 
affects me, the far off planet, and the wheat field. Keep being dynamic.

comments.text:
v = d/t; where d = distance and t = time

This is one of the most basic equations in physics and is frankly the first 
thing you learn in any introductory physics course. 

v = 300,000,000 meters / 1 second

This is the velocity of light. If what you are proposing were to be true, 
then light would travel at 300,000,000 meters per 0 seconds (truly 
instant), which is literally impossible (try it in a calculator). Even if 
in some crazy circumstance this were possible, imagine the consequences 
that would result from this. Velocity would be completely irrelevant. 
Traveling from Florida to London would take 0 seconds, and from London to 
Paris 0 seconds. Taking two steps would take 0 seconds. All sense of time 
would be lost, the universe would cease to exist. In fact, it would have 
never existed in the first place (it would have existed 0 seconds).

It's actually a rather interesting scenario.

Now, what I assume you were trying to say, was that if light were to 
suddenly change and all else stayed the same. Again, completely impossible 
under any bounds of physics. As to what it would look like, I'm sure it 
would be fascinating and one can only dream.

comments.text:
+Bird Jesus I think the idea is that the blue color "bleeds" onto the white 
and fools most people into seeing a blue circle. 

The effect didn't really work for me, however, many optical illusions 
don't. I'm a photographer and I have spent a lot of time over the years, 
both consciously and subconsciously, training my mind to visualize the 
world more like my camera. Many optical illusions that used to work on my 
don't any more. For example, tungsten light (ordinary incandescent light 
bulbs) never really look white to me anymore, they look orange. (Not as 
orange as they show up on daylight balanced film or digital sensors, but 
never anywhere near white). Another example, is that illusion with the 
checker board pattern and the box casting a shadow, where the light square 
in the shadow is the same shade as the dark square in the light never works 
on me anymore, either.

Yeah peripheral vision is pretty important despite it being blury. It has a 
higher "frame rate" than  foval vision which would figure as it has lots of 
tieins with limbic system responses such as threat detection.
Annother interesting one is to look at yourself in a mirror. Notice 
anything different if you look at end of your nose, or look  yourself in 
the  eye? To me the bluring of different facial details illustrates just 
how much visual perception is like autosterograms. It can be done with one 
eye, but if with two eyes you use two trigonometry allows you to work out 
just how much concious control one can exert over where your eyes are 
looking. It's less than 0.2 deg and I beleive in certain circumstance that 
can be perceived . It's also better than what most eye tracking equipment 
can manage.

top_comment.text:
So I have a burning question...if you were in a car traveling faster than 
the speed of light, and you had your headlights, on would you see the light 
in front of you? Or would it be behind you? ﻿
top_comment.author: Ashley Roberts

comments.text:
Well I can't tell what would happen at the speed of light or greater, as 
that is physically impossible. However I can tell you what happens at 99% 
of the speed of light.
According to the Theory of Special Relativity, you would see the light in 
front of you, as not seeing it would violate the Principle of Relativity 
(i.e you would be able to determine you were in an inertial frame of 
reference, which is not possible).
 So you would see the light. However the speed of light is a constant for 
all observers, meaning that someone standing on the side of the road can't 
see the light reflected back into your eyes, as they would see light 
travelling at twice its normal speed. What changes is your's and the 
observer's perception of time. For you, time would go much slower than it 
does for the observer. Time is relative.
comments.author: Jaxcab73

comments.text:
if you travel faster then the speed of light you will see a little white 
spot in the front direction ( whiter than the whitest thing we know ), and 
anything else will become dark and blurry ( 90 degrees to any direction 
looking towards the white spot ), and behind - it will be the perfect black 
!
comments.author: Armen Nazaryan

comments.text:

I've got a flying Vsaucer. I need your thumbs up to get this question to 
Vsauce's attention.

Your size in 4D
Every single cell inside your body as an adult is foreign to what was your 
body as a kid. So your adult body has absolutely nothing to do with your 
body as a kid.
So here's the thought experiment:
Let's suppose someone were to be born inside a room twice their size and 
live there for 20 years never having left the room once.

Nothing that leave's the body leaves the room. No shed skin, no haircuts, 
no exhale, waste, urine, tears, nothing. All necessary food, air, and water 
come in through a feeding tube, and all exhale remains.

How much of each element would be in the room to keep an average man alive 
throughout their lifetime.

In other words how many pounds of each element would the average human have 
accumulated by age 80?﻿

+Yasin Nouri "Not everyone has an accent"  Ahem.  Yes, *everyone* has an 
accent.  What we call an accent is a flag that someone's speech pattern is 
different from our own - ie: a measure of relativity.  To say someone has 
no accent IS having an accent - the same one you do.

Also, given the origins of English, "no accent" would be a very 
cosmopolitan mix of Roman, German, French, and Nordic inflections, and that 
would be very distinctly an accent by anyone's judgement.  Most especially 
yours.

Interesting fact:  The average person blinks about 15,000 times in a day.  
As crazy as it sounds.  Each blink is about 0.15 seconds.  Which means your 
eyes are closed because of blinks for about 2250 seconds or about 37.5 
minutes a day. 
And in the whole year, your eyes are closed for about 228 hours because of 
blinking.  Or just over 9 days on average.
If you like fun facts and have some free time, I make videos over the facts 
that most people missed.  Have a good one.!﻿

+Zestence Though in the field of vision it can be explained by more than an 
abstract pixel, it's angular segments of the visual field.
comments.author: ganondorfchampin

comments.text:
There is no single size for a pixel, it depends on the display. A pixel is 
a unit, or a single dot, in your visual range. Even if a pixel was the size 
of an apartment building, it would still be just one pixel. Comparing an 
old CRT TV-set with a modern mobile phone for example, the TV is larger, 
yet it has fewer pixels, and you can even tell individual pixels apart with 
a magnifying glass.

Defining the display size for the brain is very difficult, since there 
technically is no display at all, the eye and the brain are quite different 
from electronic cameras and displays.

comments.text:
He explains the answer at around 5:44, where he says it is 576 megapixels, 
which would be 24,000,000 x 24,000,000 pixels if it was on a perfectly 
square grid. However, our eyes are not square, and they also can only see 
at its best vision in the fovea, the very center 2° of our field of vision 
(explained at 3:24).

If we factored this in, the field of vision in the fovea would only be 
about 7 megapixels, and the blurrier parts on the outside of that area 
would only contain about another megapixel, which would be difficult to 
calculate the number of exact pixels because they would be in inside a 
circle rather than a square.

top_comment.author: dragonhart6505

comments.text:
+dragonhart6505 To be clear, both megapixels and x-by-y integers are an 
expression of pixel resolution (i.e. if it expresses megapixels, then it 
expresses resolution).

The video does express pixel resolution in megapixels, but it does not give 
specific integer components sufficient enough to determine the aspect ratio 
(although given that the human field of vision is supposedly 180x135 
degrees, this would imply that the ratio is 4:3).

With a bit of fuzzy math (considering that this seems to include the less 
spatially-detailed areas outside of the fovea), assuming an even resolution 
in this instance would probably yield 3264 x 2448.

Note that pixel density is not mentioned here in the video and would be 
hard to measure: it's typically an absolute measurement of resolution 
divided by screen dimensions. When you're talking about our vision, you'd 
have to decide what element is used in providing the physical measurement-- 
the object, the cornea, the fovea, etc.
comments.author: Logan de la Cebra

comments.text:
Thats mega pixels/pixel density...not aspect ratio/resolution. My 3mp 
camera phone shoots 1280x720 (16:9) so
comments.author: dragonhart6505

comments.text:

information).

captions.text: Hey, Vsauce. Michael here.
I am at the White House, in America's capital,

Washington, D.C. America makes a lot of
feature films every year -

Hollywood. But they don't make the most
feature films every year. Nigeria makes more.

But the country that makes the most
films every single year is
India. Every two years, the country

of India fills up enough film with unique
feature films

that stretch all the way from this city,
Mumbai, to where I live,

in London. That's double what Hollywood
produces in two years.
That is a lot of movies, but is

real-life a movie? I've discussed the frame
rate of the human eye before but how
does the resolution
of the human eye compare to a camera or screen?
VHS, LaserDisc, DVD,

Blu-ray, IMAX. Numbers like these are
pixel dimensions. When multiplied

they tell us the total number of picture
elements an image is made up of.

A figure often used to describe digital
cameras. It might sound like

more is better, but to be sure numbers
like 1920 by 1080

are not resolutions per se.
More pixels is only part
of the equation. Resolution is about distinguishing
fine details and that depends on a lot of other factors.

For instance, the amount of light, the
size of the sensors,

what the millions of pixels are actually
encoding and
how close the subject is. I mean, up close

Salvador Dali's painting of his wife
looking at the Mediterranean can be
resolved into boxes. But from a far,

well, it's Abraham Lincoln. For crying out
loud, on a small enough screen

from far enough away, low and high,
so-called resolutions on screens, aren't
even resolved differently
from one another by your eye.

How different nearby pixels are from one
another also matters. This is called
spatial resolution.
For instance, if I go out-of-focus

the number of pixels in the video frame
stays the same but you can't resolve as much
detail. Now, with all this in mind we can still

compare human vision to a digital image,
by asking a better question.

Assuming everything else is optimal, how
many pixels would you need to make an

image on a screen large enough to fill
your entire field of view

look like real life, without any
detectable
pixelation? Now we are getting somewhere.
Kind of. The analogy is still crudy

because a camera snaps an entire frame
at once, whereas
our eyes move around. The brain amalgamates

their constant stream of information
into what we call vision -

sight. In fact, the image created by the
eyeball alone during a single glance

would hardly even be acceptable on a
broken TV screen. We think

our eyes create images like this picture
Guy took of me with a camera.

But for one thing, unlike a camera,
you've got some stuff
in the way. For instance, you are always

looking at your own nose, and maybe even
glasses,

if you have them. Luckily, our brains
process those stimuli out because they
don't matter

and they don't change. But thinking those are
the only difference
is a pitfall, literally,
latinly. The fovea gets its name from the Latin for

'pitfall'. The fovea is the pit on your
retina that receives light from the
central two degrees

of your field of view, about the area
covered by both your thumbs

when held at arms length away. Optimal
colour vision and 20/20 acuity are

only possible within that little area.
When it comes to these limitations XKCD[.com]
has a brilliant illustration.
It points out other problems, like blind spots - literal blank spaces

in our vision where the optic nerve meets
up with the retina
and no visual information is received. If you bought
a camera that did this, you would return it.
You can find your own blind spot by closing

your right eye, fixating your left eye
on a point in front of you,
extending your left thumb and then moving it

left-of-center slightly slowly carefully
until

it's not there anymore. Crazy(!)
But, of course,

we don't see the world horribly, like
this, because our eyes are constantly moving,
dragging foveal resolution wherever we need it.
And our brains' complex visual system fills in details,

merges images from both eyes and makes a
lot of gueses. What we actually see

is a processed image.
Not computer-generated imagery, but,

well, meat-generated imagery.
The neon color spreading illusion

is a great way to demonstrate this
difference. There is no
blue circle in this picture. The white here
is the same as the white here. A camera
isn't fooled, a screen isn't fooled, only

you and the fleeting gumbo of
ingredients you call perception
is fooled. Our vision

is not analogous to a camera. But our
reformulated question can still be

answered because human anatomy allows us
